channel.title: Dandenong Ranges Hemiptera
channel.description: All true bugs, their eggs or nymphs found in the Dandenong Ranges area which includes the area from Police Paddocks to Upper Beaconsfield to Cockatoo to Mt Evelyn.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This small Cicadidae was attracted to light. I haven't seen these green patterns before. Yoyetta?

item.title: Eurymeloides marmorata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 10mm long; exploring the leaves of a eucalyptus sapling.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A small seed bug type found on my young coriander leaves. Miridae, Lygaeidae? Alydidae maybe.. Still to search...

item.title: Pentatomidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Austromalaya reticulatus should not be in Victoria? And this one was dark... returning with more info.

item.title: Amorbus alternatus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Clown bugs. Like Crusader bug without the cross.

item.title: Mictis profana
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Large correid bug found at the edge of Dandenong Ranges NP on acacia

item.title: Macroceps tonnoiri
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description:
An interesting little bull-headed mottled hopper on small eucy sapling. About 14mm long.
I have matched features and patterns to 'Macroceps tonnoiri' http://www1.dpi.nsw.gov.au/keys/leafhop/species/mtonnoir.htm (Cicadellidae: Tartessinae: Thymbrini)

item.title: Aphalaridae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description:
About 12mm body length. These psylloideans insert eggs into leaves or stems which develop into galls to house developing nymphs. https://www.flickr.com/photos/69610519@N08/6683564239/in/photostream/ http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:16e0872c-89ee-4cd3-b80e-8dd3227de0de#tab_gallery
Stephen Thorpe on BowerBird has IDed this one and after much reading I think we need to add Aphalaridae
order HEMIPTERA suborder STERNORRHYNCHA superfamily PSYLLOIDEA family APHALARIDAE

item.title: Schedotrioza spp.
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: These small dry star-bursts of psyllid galls looked like rusted metal flowers stuck to the upper surfaces of gum leaves. These eruptions looked a lot "neater" than some of the galls induced by these little hemipterans. Spotted on what looked like Silver-leaf Stringy Bark ( E.cinerea) in a reserve.

item.title: Bathyllus albicinctus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Small spittlebug or froghopper hiding in leaf axil.

item.title: Yoyetta celis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Silver Princess yoyetta... but found on acacia stem.

item.title: Stenolemus bituberus
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: A delicate-looking predacious bug from the Reduviidae family. The long legs were covered with fuzzy setae. The mid and hind legs were resting on the web silk while the front pair of legs were held up folded in front of the head. The antennae looked much like another pair of legs.

item.title: Ipoella spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 10mm long. Two at consecutive nodes with one looking like it had just moulted and was unfurling wings? Subfamily Eurymelinae: Tribe Ipoini; Genus Ipoella ?.

item.title: Cixiidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 10mm long. A face that would work in an alien sci-fi movie. Still searching for species.

item.title: Achilus flammeus
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 15mm long. Very dark red elytra with bright red margins and tiny spots of white all over. The rest of the bug is an almost iridescent pink red. Resting under light on a stone wall in an outer urban back yard. This is a particularly dark specimen. They are also called 'Red fungus bug'. Also accidentally introduced to the northern parts of New Zealand although there is a theory that they may have been 'blown' over there by prevailing weather patterns. order: HEMIPTERA suborder: AUCHENORRHYNCHA infraorder: FULGOROMORPHA superfamily: FULGOROIDEA family: ACHILIDAE subfamily: Achilinae tribe: Achilini

item.title: Oliarus spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This one turned up in our back yard. Resting on a strawberry plant. About 8mm long. Cixiid hopper, tribe Pentastirini, genus Oliarus.

item.title: Cermatulus nasalis nasalis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Predatory shield bug. They often grab prey much larger than themselves for a quick snack. About 20mm long On acacia stems in a local nature reserve. Glenfern Valley.

item.title: Poecilometis patruelis patruelis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Pentatomoidean bug about 20mm long body. Searching for this one... Found in Silver acacia leaves at a local nature reserve. http://bie.ala.org.au/species/urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:018eae6d-32c0-44d6-86f9-1c9c7f75e1dd#

item.title: Diplonychus eques
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 18mm long. This streamlined looking bug was attracted to night lights at the local school. A long way from the nearest flowing water.

item.title: Diemenia rubromarginata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Approximately 16mm long not including antennae. Resting on the only dark knot on a large barkless eucalyptus log... trying not to be noticed.
